September 9, 1914.

Mr. Luk Shin Cho

Tang Shan, China

My dear Luk:

Your letter of April 27th reached me during the sumor, and the

accompanying draft for $300. has been handed to the Treasurer to repay in

part the loan made you before you left for home.

I shall hope to receive

the balance at your convenience, though I realize that just now it may be

difficult to transmit funds.

I was very sorry to leam that you have been ill, but trust that

by this time you are entirely recovered and are thoroughly enjoying yourself

with your family and friends, and among familiar scenes.

I understand that

Kwan is to bring a half dozan Chinese students to us this fall, provided the

war does not interfere with the journey.

Another Chinese boy named Chow has

just written me from Holyoke, so that we shall probably have a good Chinese

delegation this year.

I suppose the war is interesting you all intensely out there in the

far East. In view of all that has occurred I hope that the world will come 
to realize that the boasting vest has no special claim to the possession of

civilization, and that some of the finest traits of civilization that are

enduring and really worth while can be seen in their best form among that

ancient people of which you are privileged to be one.

I earnestly hope that

China will not get drawn into the whirlpool, but will continue to stand for

peace and honor, courtesy and reverence.

My best wishes to you, as always.

Faithfully yours,

metadata.abstract: Letter stating that Luk's letter of 27 April arrived during the summer along with the $300. He was sorry to hear of Luk's illness and adds that the Chinese delegation will number 6 students this fall, provided that the war does not prevent their attendance. Chow, a student from Holyoke, will also attend. He expresses his hope that the west will not lay special claim to the possession of civilization and that China will stand for peace and honor, courtesy and reverence.
